author: Darren Turner
content: Who’s out buying an electric vehicle during the Easter holidays?  Electric vehicle sales are rocketing and there is no turning off the taps, even in an overall depressed new vehicle registration market.  What do we mean?  March saw overall new car registrations decline by 14.3% to 243,479 units during the month, which was the weakest March since 1998.  Why?  Because of supply constraints driven by semi-conductor (micro-chip) shortages and a shortage of wiring looms, which would normally be sourced from Ukraine.  Although electric vehicles are bucking this trend, with 39,315 new registrations during March, which is an increase of a whopping 78.7% against the same time last year.  Here’s an amazing stat. More electric vehicles were purchased in March than in the whole of 2019.  The industry (dealerships and leasing companies) is still reporting overall strong sales, but it’s the supply constraints causing the delays of these turning into new registrations.  But with grants for electric vehicles ongoing to at least next March, interest rates still low, high fuel costs and electric cars benefitting from lower running costs, there are significant benefits for drivers who can order an electric vehicle sooner rather than later.  In-conjunction with this, during April, Evolution Solutions are providing a £50 discount on all home charge point installations if it’s installed within 3 weeks of order placement.  Your EV might be slightly delayed, but you can still ‘SAVE £50’ by not delaying your home charge point installation.  …apply now at https://lnkd.in/dgadyQV

author: Masters Union Investment Fund
content: A semiconductor crisis amid the Russia-Ukraine war?  In 2021, semiconductor sales reached $555.89 billion worldwide. Semiconductor materials are an essential component of electronic devices, making them vital for almost all major industries, including communications, computing, healthcare, military systems, transportation, and clean energy. The year-over-year growth rate in 2021 is expected to reach 26.2 percent.  According to Moody's Analytics analysis, palladium and neon are two resources that are key to the production of semiconductor chips, given that Russia supplies over 40 percent of the world’s supply of palladium and Ukraine produces 70 percent of the global supply of neon. The global chip shortage is expected to worsen should the military conflict persist.  Given that the Russia-Ukraine conflict persists and the current global economic conditions, the Federation of Automobile Dealers Associations (FADA) changed the automotive industry’s outlook from "neutral" to "negative". The automotive industry accounts for just 12% of the overall semiconductor market. So, one can imagine the impact of semi-conductor supplies on other industries.  A lot of countries are making investments to remove or dilute the impact of frequent semiconductor crises. Spain recently announced plans to spend 11 billion euros on the semiconductor industry.   Our Prime Minister, Mr. Narendra Modi, said that India should move towards self-reliance in the semiconductor business. The government of India has launched various PLI incentives for the manufacturing of electronic components with semiconductors to the extent of $30 billion to position India as a global hub.  For investments, major companies to track in this space are Vedanta , Tata Elxsi, ASM Technologies Ltd, Moschip Technologies Ltd, SPEL, Ruttonsha International Rectifier Ltd.  Investment Thoughts by Akshay Kumar - Masters' Union #manufacturing #business #automotiveindustry #investments #semiconductor #russiaukrainewar #investing #muif #mastersunion

author: Rajesh Satyavada
content: Pursue your dreams and you shall be happy!  11 years ago, with a 3-year Masters degree in Electrical Engineering from US of A and loads of over-confidence on my mind, I went knocking on the doors of #intel in India for an opportunity to start my dream - To build circuits , tiny little circuits.  To my disappointment, I failed, and I failed over and over again for next 7 months and remained job-less. The failures eventually cut through my over-confidence and brought me to ground. All this while during my job hunt, I was receiving calls from software firms to which I was hell bent to not interact, thanks to my ego,   My ego -> "I have a MS in EE from USA, why should I take up a software job, my 3 years would go down the drain"  But little did I know that the universe was plotting against me all this while. My mother, a banker, gave me an ultimatum (as I was free loading under her roof for past 7 months),   "Rajesh, take up a job, any job, keep your pursuit for an electronics job while you work there, this will help your resume rather than doing nothing"  2011 September, I started working Amazon's Hyderabad R&D center as Dev Ops engineer. This was a time where Amazon.com was yet to foray the Indian e-commerce world. I learnt about e-commerce Industry, learnt to code, understood Data-centers and even explored Extract Transform and Loads of Data Transformation. #amzn. This was probably an interesting phase of my life where I felt, "Hey, this is a great place to work, I am learning, but what about my dreams to build circuits?   Yet again, 7 months into "Dev-Opsing", opportunity knocked my door in the form #synopsys . I received a call from the hiring manager who looked up my linkedIn profile ( yes, year 2012 LinkedIn was beginning to show its value) and asked if I would be interested to join their team as an Intern. I jumped out of my seat and accepted the offer without a second thought. I quit my decently paying job at Amazon and joined as an intern at Synopsys-India, building Process Design Kits. This marked the beginning of my journey in the world of semi-conductors.  Today, I complete a decade in this Industry and I am on the verge completing 3 years at Intel, where my hunt had all started. I could not have been happier than what I am today <3.  There is nothing more satisfying than doing what you love!  I have become an electronics engineer, who loves to code , and that is a combination that has helped me automate circuit design.  I am thankful to my failures and to all the Leaders, mentors and friends from #amzn #synopsys and #intel who taught me the importance of being patient, creative and most importantly to do what you love <3.  Cheers!  #electronics #electricalengineering #careerstories #vlsi #semiconductor

author: Andy Zook
content: Yesterday was about #relationships and when thinking about Asia, size matters, both physical and population.  In thinking about expanding, a big market to sell into always helps.    Asia is a really big place, but because the US is the biggest single language country in population, sometimes we forget how big.    Some perspective on the geography, in the US we think flying from NY to LA takes long at 4.5 hours.  If you went from Singapore to Mumbai, Beijing, Tokyo, or Sydney, those trips would take a minimum of 6 hours.    The above destinations from Singapore are the Big 4 - Australia, China, India, and Japan.  These are the markets everyone opening up in Asia is going after.  These markets present very different competitive dynamics. By example, Australia’s continent is as large as the United States, but with a population of 25.8 million mostly living on the coast.  Think about how distribution would work if everyone lived on the coastline or borders of the US.  Contrast that with India and China both over 1 billion people rapidly moving up in disposable income.   	 Small in land, does not mean small in impact.  In Asia you have many countries which are not the physical size of the Big 4, but have significant economic clout.  Singapore and Hong Kong in financial services, South Korea and Taiwan in high technology and semi-conductors, Malaysia on natural resources.  Each of these countries have their own cultures and heritage, so you have to understand its history before jumping in.    In addition to India and China, there are many countries of Asia that have populations close or above 100M, Indonesia, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Japan, Philippines, and Vietnam.  As a comparison, Germany with 83M people is the largest Western European country.    Having big markets to go after is great, but focus creates success.    Please share your thoughts or an interesting fact about your market.  #entrepreneur #international #sales

author: OECC VIỆT NAM
content: Khóa luận tốt nghiệp trong tiếng Anh: Định nghĩa, ví dụ https://lnkd.in/gmAhVqqq  Khóa luận tốt nghiệp tiếng Anh là gì?  Graduate thesis ( Noun)  Nghĩa tiếng Việt: Khóa luận tốt nghiệp  Nghĩa tiếng Anh: Graduate thesis  (Nghĩa của khóa luận tốt nghiệp trong tiếng Anh)  Từ đồng nghĩa  minor thesis  Ví dụ:  Quyển khóa luận tốt nghiệp này trở thành luận án tiến sĩ ở Princeton.  This graduate thesis became a dissertation at Princeton.  Tôi thậm chí đã viết bài khóa luận tốt nghiệp về thuyết của Darwin.  I had even written my graduate thesis on Darwinian theory.  Vì tôi hoàn thành khóa luận tốt nghiệp 4 tháng trước hạn chót.  Because I finished my graduate thesis four months before the deadline.  Bài khóa luận tốt nghiệp của tôi nói về mối quan hệ giữa yakuza và phe dân tộc cực đoan thuộc phe cánh hữu sau chiến tranh ở Nhật.  My graduate thesis was about the relationship between the yakuza and ultranationalist right-wing politics in post-war Japan.  Đó… là một bài khóa luận tốt nghiệp rất hay.  That… was really a very good graduate thesis.  Tôi đã làm đề tài khóa luận tốt nghiệp về bộ nhớ bán dẫn.  I did my graduate thesis on semi-conductor memory.  Trong khóa luận tốt nghiệp đại học.  For my graduate thesis in college.  Và nếu em không nghĩ điều đó đúng cô sẽ rất vui cho em mượn bài khóa luận tốt nghiệp.  And if you think that’s not true, I’d be happy to lend you my graduate thesis.  Và khi tôi viết bài khóa luận tốt nghiệp của mình về điện thoại di động,  And when I was writing my graduate thesis on cell phones,  Dù sao cũng không ai thèm quan tâm tới bài khóa luận tốt nghiệp của em.  Nobody cares about your graduate thesis anyway.  Thời sinh viên, tôi đã làm khóa luận tốt nghiệp về ông ta.  When I was a student I did my graduate thesis on him.  Tôi không muốn tự trói buộc mình, nhưng tôi nghĩ khóa luận tốt nghiệp của cô sẽ có chiều sâu hơn… nếu nó nói về một người đang nắm cốt lõi của vấn đề.  I don’t want to impose myself, but I’m sure your graduate thesis would gain dept h if it was on a man who’s at the core of the problem.  Từ khóa luận tốt nghiệp của cậu.  From your graduate thesis.  Anh sinh viên đó đã làm một khóa luận tốt nghiệp xuất sắc,  And the student did a wonderful graduate thesis,  Đó là về khóa luận tốt nghiệp của em. Em sẽ giải thích với anh sau.  It’s about my graduate thesis, I’ll explain it to you later.  Sau cuộc hành trình đi về phía Nam, tài liệu này vẫn còn được cất giữ trong một thùng đựng đồ trong nhiều năm và sau đó nói chung là không được ai biết cho đến khi nó được đăng trong khóa luận tốt nghiệp vào năm 2000.  After the trek South, it remained packed in a trunk for several years and then was generally unknown until it was published in a graduate thesis in 2000.  Khóa luận tốt nghiệp của họ là một số nhóm ở Mỹ tốt hơn những nhóm khác dựa trên ba đặc điểm văn hóa, được mô tả trong sách này, mang đến cho các nhóm này một lợi thế. author: Allison Dolan
content: The paradoxes of the US in one week's worth of stories (most of which have nothing to do with the war in Ukraine.)  -- Just 34 of the world's nations are liberal democracies, down almost 20% from 2012; only 13% of the world's population live in a liberal democracy (free elections, rule of law, individual rights)  - US wages gained 5.6%;  more than 90% of pre-pandemic jobs have been reclaimed; unemployment is near record lows; there have been 11 straight months of job growth > 400K (the longest streak in at least 8 decades); job participation rate among 25-54 now >80%; 2021 was the profitable year for American corporations since 1950  -- US inflation is highest in 4 decades; the median pay for the leader of an S&P 500 company was $14.2million; Jassy (Amazon) is paid almost 6,500 times the median Amazon worker; Ukraine produces 1/2 the world's neon an critical component of semi-conductor chips (which are used in cars)   - Because Florida counted tourists and seasonal residents in their vaccine count, there are more than 100 FL zip codes reporting vaccination figures that exceed the total residents, in some cases by a factor of 10.  -- Nearly 1/2 of gay teens have seriously considered suicide, and more than half of all teens reported experiencing emotional abuse by a parent or adult at home.  --There were at least 219 US tornadoes in March, the highest number since 1950, vs last year's record 191 and compared to the average of 80.  -- Barack Obama Presidential Library is getting FOIA requests about the secret WH party for pedophiles.   -- to prosecute Trump for 1/6 requires proving he had 'criminal intent'.  He could defend himself simply by saying he just listened to his lawyer (Eastman) about what legally could be done.

author: Harrison Jnr Ilodigwe, MCIPS, CSCP
content: The glocal (global & local) economic landscape is changing rapidly, creating a delicate demand-supply imbalance for almost everything and exposing the vulnerabilities of global supply chains as a result.  Today, we are witnessing a slow global recovery from the impact of COVID-19, an energy crisis in Nigeria, lingering logistics bottlenecks, scarcity of FX, escalating shipping costs, an uncertain political landscape, cashflow & working capital squeezes, volatile exchange rates, policy somersaults, semi-conductor and shipping container shortages along with the prolonged Russia-Ukraine conflict. Simply put, the impact of the global supply chain disruption is not leaving anytime soon.  What's your organisation's supply chain doing to stay afloat and weather the second and third order impacts?  If you work within the Procurement & Supply Chain function, please join our community The Supply Chain Network here in Nigeria and our colleagues on The Supply Chain Network Uganda, next Sunday April 10, 2022 for an open roundtable to share thoughts on your experiences and listen to what your peers are doing to navigate the complexities of the rapidly evolving supply chain environment.   Please register in advance via the link below. This promises to be exciting.  Ifeanyi Ojoh -MCIPS Chartered, M.Sc, Sheila Birungi,  CPIM, CSCP, Obalim Hilary, MCIPS (In-view), Mini-MBA (TEKEDIA) https://lnkd.in/dYen7FvW

author: India Science
content: Almost all #electronic devices use #semiconductors and most of them use #silicon based semi-conductors. India has announced a multi-billion dollar Indian semi-conductor mission to try and create a full #ecosystem of semi-conductors.  There is an even more advanced class of semi-conductors called compound semi-conductors where chips are made using more than one element and hence, are dubbed compound semi-conductors. India has invested heavily in this area of semi-conductors with the Solid State Physics Laboratory a part of the Defence Research and Development Organisation leading the charge. The New Delhi based facility is truly a hidden jewel and has a full lab to fab culture. It works on all the highest end semi-conductors like silicon carbide, gallium arsenide, gallium nitride, it specialises from making all the materials like the basic raw material of ingots to fabricating the chips and devices. These compound semi-conductors are hard to make and rather expensive but have found place in India’s specialised strategic devices. The laboratory is unique in one more way it is headed by a lady director and it is considered one of the best facilities not only in India but in the world. Since it caters to India’s defence needs its work remains low key. The lab also works on semi-conductor diodes and lasers.  The DRDO facility also houses many clean rooms and a research and development fabrication facility to make designer chips. A futuristic project it is working on is to try and use a laser beam to transmit audio and text based data, this could be applicable in communicating with submarines. India leads in research on compound semi-conductors as the lab was set up almost 60 years ago and it has done remarkably well in this cutting edge sector.   Vigyan Prasar

author: SCM Talent Group - Executive Supply Chain Recruiters
content: This article discusses how America can improve its semi-conductor supply chain in a time of extreme disruption.  Ukraine controls a lot of the neon gas which is used for lasers that cut microprocessors for the chips. Geopolitical disruptions along with the Pandemic are cause for major concern for the West who rely heavily on these volatile regions for semiconductors.  One such concern is talent during a supply chain labor shortage. Should immigration laws be relaxed to allow for a larger talent pool?  It sounds like a combination of policy initiatives and private sector advances might be the best route. However, as with most things supply chain and supply chain talent, things are very fluid at the moment.  #supplychain #talent #hiring https://lnkd.in/gP4-fR3x

author: Dave P. Buemi
content: This great work is another example of rapidly advancing perovskite solar development.   A perovskite cell stack is comprised > 6 discreet layers and high throughput manufacturing of all cell stack layers in the same process, at the same speed, is paramount to reaching significantly lower cost than the competition.  Progress on printing the charge transport layers demonstrated here is an important and notable lab scale accomplishment toward this manufacturing goal.   But the key to achieving marketing leading cost is to print all cell stack layers at the same high speed. Printing a few layers but then using slow, high cost semi-conductor processes for the other layers doesn't move the cost needle low enough to have competitive advantage.   #perovskitesolar #energyinnovation #solarpv #photovoltaics #energypolicy #energytransition

Motor claims is battling a perfect storm, induced by macro-economic events following on from the pandemic including significant repairer capacity issues, vehicle supply shortages, fuel and energy price hikes, insufficient semi-conductor chips for vehicle production, and shortage of skilled resource at the same time that we face the separate issues caused by the increasing numbers of EV." author: Zara Hammond
content: I had my own new car day this week!! Like many of you, I personally have been affected by the global semi-conductor shortage, and have seen a couple of month delay to my new car arriving. But this week, it’s finally arrived, and despite it all I’ve well and truly got the new car feeling.   Having helped 1000’s of clients into vehicles over the years, we at P+B know from the moment you decide on “the” car, to the day it arrives, it is an important and special journey. Our entire business is built on the principle of being the good guys and providing our clients with the most transparent and honest service possbile, something that maybe isn’t so common within the automotive industry.  During what has been a tough period for all, we don’t intend to drop our standard. I’d highly recommend keeping an eye on our blog site and speaking to our team with your specific needs for the next 12 months to avoid further delays for you and your companies.   Now officially joining the world of EV, I’m very to make a greener impact on the world, create further tax savings perosnally and for P+B. The most challenging part is going to be the fact that I’m solely reliant on Charging Network Nationwide, so wish me luck!

author: Katie R.
content: For all my connections, not in the Automotive industry but have a vehicle on order, or considering ordering a vehicle. Please be aware when your vehicle is delayed, we're not fobbing you off with excuses; it's in our interest to get your vehicle to you as quickly as possible.   First Covid was causing huge delays and still continues to hinder the production even now, 2 years later, then we have the shortage of Semi-conductor chips! This article explains the latest issues we're facing. It's not easy working in our industry at the moment but we're fighting through and we're constantly trying to source you alternatives.    We do care.  We are working hard and tirelessly for you.  Please be patient.  Please be kind.

author: Philip Bates
content: I'm really pleased to have been part of the team that advised the shareholders of Global Vans on securing investment from H2 Equity Partners. Global Vans is a great business right on our doorstep and I'm sure it will grow from strength to strength in the coming years. Congratulations to all involved!  Bristol-headquartered Global Vans is a light commercial vehicle (LCV) broker, which has nationwide coverage, and organises vehicles on behalf of SME customers. It is one of the largest procurers of LCVs in the UK. The team at Global Vans is expert in its field and has navigated the challenges of the recent semi-conductor and LCV shortages. Now, with the support of H2, the founders (Andrew Hurst and Jonathan Lewis) will continue to lead the business and work closely with H2 to realise Global Vans' ambitious growth strategy.  KPMG in Bristol provided Corporate Finance and Tax advice to the shareholders. The team was Tim Spooner, Philip Bates, Tomas Castka, Jacob Leach, Edward Brown, Adam Shaw, David Harris and Steve Brand #KPMGcorporatefinance #KPMGdeals #automotive #kpmgdeals #manda #privateequity #deals

author: KNX Association
content: Featured new KNX Product - ON Semiconductor - NCN5140S KNX Switch:  The NCN5140S integrates the market leading ON semi-conductor KNX transceiver and an ARM Cortex-M0+ microcontroller, together with the majority of the necessary passive components, into one package, allowing the design of ultra-slim KNX switch applications. Combined with a certified KNX stack and pre-certified software for up to eight configurable rocker or touch switch buttons, the KNX system-in-package enables the development of KNX switch applications in a very short time frame. The pre-certified application software includes driving and dimming up to eight RGB LED to illuminate the buttons or touch pads. Registration of a derivative design at KNX Association is sufficient to achieve KNX certification.  www.onsemi.com

author: Jeff Hayes
content: Since last Summer, I've talked endlessly about why dealers should continue advertising, even through the new car shortage.  Advertising through any kind of market disruption is CRUCIAL because it keeps you top of mind. The end result (which you can't see now) is a larger market share.    The end result of being invisible? You LOSE market share (which you also can't see now).  What I've learned over the past six months from dealerships who haven't let off the gas is:  - they've been able to create a lot of buzz around the inventory they have on the ground and on the way - they're getting a lot of traffic and talking to more prospects than expected (thanks in part to their competition who stopped advertising)   - many customers are willing to wait for a custom order or buy a CPO vehicle  If nothing else, you've touched more people. Even if it doesn't pay off today, it will pay off tomorrow.    Maybe the supply chain will fix itself. Maybe the $52 billion Senate semi-conductor bill solves it. Either way, this time will pass. What you do or don't do now WILL impact your future.   Whether things improve at your stores next month, six months from now, or next year, don't let up.    - Keep your customers updated and engaged  - Stay on course with a well-thought out ad strategy  - Adapt and adjust as needed.  But no matter what... stay consistent. The chips are coming!  #cardealers #automotiveadvertising #digitalmarketing

Discover what happened here: https://lnkd.in/dcGbZYJd. The latest #ArvalMobilityObservatory video goes through the reasons why car manufacturers are experiencing such a supply chain shortage and highlights some actions that companies and countries are taking, in order for them to decrease their dependency on Asia.  Enjoy watching and stay tuned!   #battery #connectedvehicle #EV

author: Yasmina SABER
content: Tokyo, JAPAN -- April 11, 2022 Nation Based on Science: Instead of Licensing from Foreign Countries, Japan own Scientific Achievements breed Homegrown Technologies!  Remarkably, in 1986 the mounting U.S. trade deficit in semi conductors with Japan even led to a trade agreement easing the situation. The Japanese semiconductor industry was expanding rapidly. Technologically, this was the outcome of the most successful of the so-called Big Projects I described in a previous article: The research association for the very-large-scale integrated circuit VLSI (1976-1980) helped push Japan’s semiconductor industry to world level.  Managed by the Agency of Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) since the mid-1960s, the Big Projects proved well to assist the country’s economic rise.  By 1980, Japan’s industries had accomplished hitting the technological frontier in many areas. The time of catching up was over. The government proclaimed that Japan was becoming a “Nation based on Science and Technology.” Instead of licensing from foreign countries, own scientific achievements should breed homegrown technologies.  What happened after this decision? Japan increased its spending on science and technology in the private and public sectors. While in the 1970s it stood below 2 percent of GDP, in 1990 it had already reached 2.8 percent.   https://lnkd.in/dc2PfgKU

author: Neil Holloway
content: Suppliers holding materials price quotes for just 24 hours - is this common place across the industry?  Some interesting insights in this article:  Some manufacturers of energy-intensive products are now warning that surcharges will be slapped on products linked to surging energy costs.  The cost of energy is impacting manufacturers across Europe, with reports of cement plants in Spain closing due to the latest increases.  In the UK manufacturers report the supply picture remains broadly stable in terms of full production with good stocks and availability of most products.  But supply challenges continue to affect bricks, aircrete blocks, roof tiles, gas boilers, plastic drainage and other plastic products dependent on polymers, and some electrical products particularly those using semi-conductors.  Manufacturers are warning that while brick and block stocks have also increased slightly during the quieter winter month as the market accelerates in the spring it will be essential for builders to plan ahead and work with manufacturers to ensure timelines of availability.  The boiler market has been impacted by unprecedented demand coupled with supply chain challenges for steel, cardboard, plastics and electronic components.  While availability will remain constrained over the summer months, manufacturers remain hopeful that the supply and demand will normalise by the end of the year.  On plastic products, there are reports in some areas of shortages of raw materials that could lead to spikes in prices, but indications are hopeful that this may be resolved later in the spring.  Paints and coatings continue to be affected by ongoing raw material shortages recently exacerbated by further lockdowns in China and by the war in Ukraine. This is likely to affect prices, and possibly the availability of some products over the coming months.  Looking ahead, the war in Ukraine and the resulting sanctions on Russia and Belarus are likely to constrain the supply of pallets, birch plywood and OSB (oriented strand board).  These countries are major suppliers of pallet wood and manufactured pallets, as well as large producers of the components of the resins used in wood-based panel manufacture including OSB. Russia is also one of the main sources of birch plywood, used in a variety of applications from transport and shopfitting to furniture and die cutting.  Thoughts?

author: Deepak Garg
content: Used vehicle re-sale gold rush.   Both CV and PV markets are seeing used vehicle re-sale gold rush.   The new vehicles are expensive, supply side concerns (semi-conductor shortage) and real wage-deflation is leading to increase in used-vehicle prices.   Next few months will see used vehicle prices go up higher than the book purchase price and the last time it happened was in 2010-2011 when the regulatory and steel price led increase in pricing led to an environment where used CV/PV sold at higher prices than they were purchased at.   #transport #rivigo

content: As predicted in Fall of 2021, the talent shortage around semi-conductor chips is creating some stress in the supply chain marketplace. author: Shaun Collins
content: Spain’s government recently announced a plan to invest 11 billion euro in upgrading the country’s silicon chip-making industry.  This follows hot on the heels of the European Commission’s multi-billion euro “Chips Act” announced in February this year.   The ongoing chip shortage has highlighted just how reliant the west has become on semiconductors sourced from Asia and has brought into sharp relief, a serious strategic vulnerability.   The European Union plans to sharply curtail this reliance by supporting and incentivising the region to become a centre for global semi-conductor manufacturing by 2030.  It’s an admirable goal and daunting in its scope but ensuring Europe can mitigate further shortages is not easy.   The region will also require this increase in manufacturing to offer increased innovation in the sector to keep up with the white hot levels of progress coming out of Asia and the United States if it has realistic ambitions. https://lnkd.in/eqUQk7zU #semiconductors #europeanunion

author: Kishore Nayar
content: @Mahua Venkatesh (Article author): "Vedanta-Foxconn JV may just be the beginning of India-Taiwan tech partnership At a time when global shortage of semi conductors has hit production of electronic items including smartphones and vehicles, the newly inked joint venture between the Anil Agarwal-led Vedanta and Hon Hai Technology Group – better known as Foxconn Technology Group -- to manufacture semiconductors in India naturally had grabbed headlines.  While this is expected to give a push to Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s production-linked incentive (PLI) plan, it is also seen by many as a move that would further expand collaboration between India and Taiwan, which is a key player in the global supply chain network.  The joint venture also gives shape to Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen’s “New Southbound Policy” and Modi’s Act East Policy.  "India is quietly but aggressively deepening its economic ties with Taiwan, there could be many more such investment announcements in the offing," an insider told India Narrative.  ....." author: Robert Quinn
content: KOREAN SEMI CONDUCTOR GIANT STEPS UP INTEREST IN BRITISH CHIP DESIGN FIRM  South Korean memory chip giant SK Hynix has expressed interest to take part in the acquisition of British semiconductor design company Arm, months after the SoftBank Group Corp-owned firm started preparing for an initial public offering when Nvidia Corp’s US$40 billion deal to buy it fell through. SK Hynix, the world’s second-largest memory chip maker after Samsung Electronics, is considering to co-invest in a consortium that would acquire Arm, according to a report on Wednesday by daily newspaper The Korea Herald, which quoted SK Hynix co-chief executive Park Jung-ho. “Arm plays a very important role in the international semiconductor ecosystem, and the ecosystem will not allow a single entity to take full advantage of the benefit from the acquisition,” said Park during a briefing after an SK Hynix shareholder meeting at its headquarters in Icheon, in Gyeonggi province.  Source: https://lnkd.in/ey72pYDe #semiconductor #semiconductorindustry #manufacturing #technology #computerchips #taiwan #europe #engineering

author: Pauline Gouache
content: "What's next Pauline ?"   Après 4 ans chez E.Leclerc, de très beaux projets et collaborations, je rejoins les équipes de Dealt (ex Mon Super Voisin), la solution servicielle des retailers et ecommerçants, en tant que Key Account Manager  C'est tout naturellement - cf la photo prémonitoire ci-dessous - que je rejoins cette start-up ambitieuse  qui accompagne les retailers et ecommerçants dans la définition et la gestion de leur offre de services !   Dealt c'est la solution clé en main pour passer d’un modèle de vendeur de produits à un vendeur de solutions avec +350 services disponibles, +10 000 Experts professionnels certifiés, +40 000 prestations réalisées  et déjà de très belles enseignes utilisatrices de la solution en magasin et en ecommerce : E.Leclerc , Mr.Bricolage, Botanic, Conforama, Monoprix, La Poste Groupe…   Mickael, Axel, et la dream team Dealt, merci pour votre confiance. J'ai hâte de travailler avec vous au service des top retailers français !    J'en profite pour remercier tous mes collègues E.Leclerc, en particulier l'équipe innovation qui m'a fait confiance et fait grandir : Maud, Aurelia, Christine, Brice et les autres. Merci aux centaines d'entrepreneurs et acteurs de l'écosystème inno qui ont rendu ces 4 années si riches !  Ma mission ne change pas : faire bouger le retail Si vous croyez comme moi que la prochaine révolution est servicielle, appelez-moi !   Une pensée pour Michel-Edouard Leclerc : ta vision du commerce m'accompagne  il y a 4 mois tu remettais à Dealt (ex Mon Super Voisin) le trophée de la start-up de l'année ...   #innovation #retail #services

author: Alessandro Blasi
content: What are the natural gas superpowers?   Probably many would put Russia  as the n.1. And those would have been right until the coming of #shale revolution.  Until the end of first 2000 decade the US natural gas #production was seen in an unstoppable decline to the point that the country was preparing itself for massive inflow of gas imports through #LNG terminals.   The shale revolution - started firstly with gas and then moved to oil - has changed everything. In just about more than 10 years the USA  natural gas production has doubled (basically adding an amount equivalent to full consumption of Europe), turning completely the destiny of the country and making it one of world’s largest exporter.   Its implications - well beyond #energy - are quite evident nowadays, in USA, in Europe, and everywhere else…  #oilgas #future #naturalgas #gas #technology #sustainability #innovation

author: Chloé Mikolajczak
content: New report by the Lancet says the US and Europe are responsible for the majority of global ecological damage caused by the overuse of natural resources and calls for degrowth.  It finds that over the last 40 years, the US accounted for 27% of the world’s excess material use, followed by the EU, including the UK (25%) - such as Australia, Canada, Japan and Saudi Arabia were collectively responsible for 22%.   Less wealthy nations in the global south were responsible for just 8%.  Because of the ecological debt they owe the rest of the world, “these nations need to take the lead in making radical reductions in their resource use to avoid further degradation, which will likely require transformative post-growth and degrowth approaches,” writers said.  The latest IPCC report also said that degrowth pathways may be “crucial” for combining social progress with technically feasible mitigation strategies.  Yet, the concepts of degrowth and post-growth are still very much absent from the mainstream conversations on energy, consumption, social and innovation in Europe.   For all of us working in advocacy, activism or innovation - time to change the narrative, switching to renewables on its own won't be enough, we need to recuse production and consumption: we need a new economic framework that stays within planetary boundaries while improving people's quality of life.  https://lnkd.in/e-9e_AZe

author: Claire Goyon
content: [ A page turns - Celebration from Edhec ]   In June 2016, after 2 promising years in the preparatory course, I failed on the day of the competitions. Some said, "It doesn't matter, take the schools  you had, it's already good", others "do another year, it's the only solution if you want to try your luck again, even if you won't learn no more ". Que Nenni.   I wanted to continue to learn and enrich my knowledge. I then joined the  Toulouse School of Economics in Economics Degree, where commitment, determination and perseverance were the key words of my year. Hours of work but also hours of sports and competition (because sport changes lives!), this opportunity was unique because I was able to discover subjects such as econometrics or macroeconomics which serve me again today, succeed in the results,  and retake the contest, but this time... I passed. The second chance in our lives? She does exist!   In September 2017, I joined EDHEC Business School in the Grande Ecole Program, Business Management. Then I decided to apply for the work-study program for 2 years in MSc Marketing and Business Development, within the FFF - Fédération Française de Football , as an Innovation project officer. An incredible experience with amazing collegues and a big thank you Maxime Thokagevistk for everything you have brought me. I was also committed alongside the OJO - Organisation des Jeux Omnisports, a memorable experience and a thought to all the members with whom I worked to deliver the 5th edition, can't wait to see the evolution !   In 2022, after 2 years of pandemic, it's never too late, but it's finally official - I'm graduated from EDHEC. I’m honored to also receive the prize for the "Best student award European Apprentiship Track 2020”.   A big thank you to all the teaching staff, but also to @Stephane Planque for your support in my sports practice in competition in parallel  as well as to Florence da Costa for your unfailing support and Marie FIDELIN for the coordination. Thank you to my parents who did everything for me to succeed and to my boyfriend who accompanied me in both magical and difficult times. A special dedication to my dream partner since the beginning of this EDHEC adventure, Adeline Pailhas, to whom I owe a lot.  This journey demonstrates that failure is indeed the foundation of success, combining with perseverance, determination, and Sport. Never give up, there are always solutions to bounce back.   A new page is turning but many are still to be written, including now delivering the most revolutionary and innovative Olympic and Paralympic Games in history alongside my favorite acolytes Omar El Zayat and Xavier Rolland at Paris 2024 - Comité d'organisation des Jeux Olympiques et Paralympiques de 2024 !  See you for new challenges

author: Adil Hihi
content: I was delighted to participate to the Paris Blockchain Week Summit this week with my partner in crime Azeddine ABID – the occasion to meet a boiling and diverse ecosystem. 3 days during which market makers and innovative startups shared their convictions and views regarding Blockchain, NFTs, DeFi and DAOs.   I’m glad to have shared my views during the roundtable “Stablecoins: the crucial bridge between decentralized and traditional finance" organized by La Place Fintech, alongside a quality panel – Thanks Nadia FILALI, Alban Vendeuvre, Julien Prat.  We are heading towards a tokenized world as technology is maturing. However, the biggest take-away would be a mindset change from anti-systemic posture to a much stronger willingness to work with regulators. Smart and fair regulation is crucial to allow this bubbly ecosystem to reach mass adoption while protecting consumers.   Shout-out to my personal favorite Alyra, l'école blockchain, for their dedicated work to train and upskill more than needed brilliant talents to help spread distributed technologies within our society while keeping close connections with the innovation ecosystem.  To discovering new tech breakthroughs, meeting new passionate talents and reuniting with old friends. author: Diane Gaillard
content: If you were a magician, would you change anything in your week?  Personally, I would repeat every single moment…  A couple of years ago, I took a risk and made a hard business decision, pivoting my business from full-time PR consulting to training, teaching and consulting. This week was another proof that it was the right decision!  Monday, I met up with my ISCOM international students, teaching them how to transform a prospect into a client   Tuesday, I trained a dynamic group at Publicis Groupe on public speaking   Wednesday, I had the honor to give a one-to-one pitch coaching to an entrepreneur at Leonard, the VINCI’s innovation platform    On the same day, I got the confirmation that I will continue coaching amazing entrepreneurs from the X-UP Incubator programme of École Polytechnique ️️ ️  Thursday, I gave an improvisation and pitch training to amazing intrapreneurs part of TotalEnergies thanks to INSKIP Entrepreneurs   We very often talk about the difficulties we meet, the stress we overcome or what went wrong, sometimes we talk about our achievements, but we rarely take the time to acknowledge our luck by just saying thank you to all the opportunities we are given.  Thank you all for your trust! You not only made my day but my week! A big thank you to all the great entrepreneurs & intrapreneurs I met. Your passion is contagious    Maxime Guillaud, Hugo Seviran, Léo Bonnet, Roberta Camera, Subhor Dubey, Mathilde Pruvost, Bruno CATTAN, Laurent PHILIBERT, Vincent Soulier, Elia GUITTEAUD, Gaëtan Lavigne, Lionel Doyen, Adriana Congiu, Shahrzad COUDERT, Antoine Baschiera, Camille Roy, ️ Thierry Moussu ️, Sara AID, PhD, Anne-Laure Gras #coaching #publicspeaking #incubator #startup #communication #pitch #verbalcommunication #nonverbalcommunication

author: Olivier LEPINOY
content: I remember when the Construction 4.0 book (Anil Sawhney, Prof Mike Riley and Javier Irizarry) are released. It was in February 2020.  Ken Stowe, Atul Khanzode and I co-authored a chapter titled "Innovation in the construction project delivery networks in Construction 4.0".  I thought: how did i manage to do that?  The same month came out the ENCORD foresight report, a great piece of work led by Stephanie Whittaker, co-authored with Laetitia Flourent, Nicolas Bouby, Franz Klager, with the support of Norbert Pralle, Menno de Jonge, Thierry JUIF and other key members of ENCORD.  It was my first attempt to explain the Platform Revolution and the transformation of Business Models happening in AEC. I thought: this is now printed on paper!  Last month (March 2022), this new book came out: Innovation in Construction - A Practical Guide to Transforming the Construction Industry (Seyed Hamidreza Ghaffar, CEng MICE, PhD, Paul Mullett, Eujin Pei, John T Roberts).  Carolyn Moore, Giso van der Heide MSc and I wrote together a chapter titled “Some Changes are Invisible to the Eyes: Transformation of Business Models, Organizations, and Cultures”.  I thought: I did it again!  I am proud of this work and I feel lucky that I was part of these projects. Today I think of all the individuals who did not believe in me along the past 30 years, who told me I was not relevant. They will probably never read any of this work or even this post. But I did all of this for them.   #management #innovation #technology

author: Alessandro Blasi
content: A “ nice dilemma”  What to do with all this cash ?? This is probably a recurrent question in the Hqs of largest #oilgas corporations. Coming from years of cut-to-the-bone approaches, massive upheavals for oil price crashes and pandemic tsunami and massive uncertainty on the #future of own #business, the #oilandgas industry find itself in financial conditions that – just a couple of years ago – would not have even dared to dream.   Under multiple constraints, the industry has prioritised to make its investors happy through dividends and buybacks, as well as improving its balance sheets that suffered in previous periods. But even after that, a lot of cash remain available in the pockets of big companies. While many of the largest National Oil Companies have scaled up massively their #investment plans, western companies remain more cautious to increase investment in their core business while have accelerated diversification in other areas, including #renewables, electric #mobility, #hydrogen and CCUS, just to name a few. All of this in the middle of high inflation cost environment that will inevitably affect the economics of new projects.   Current context will represent a gigantic stress test for the willingness of those companies to keep diversification strategy in sight or the high prices will encourage a focus back in their traditional domains.   The destiny of #energy security and climate change will be function also of this.     #peakoil #data #alternativeenergy #sustainability #innovation #economy #technology

author: kevin Dango Tchoupe
content: Le changement ne se fait pas à la vitesse de la lumière.     Chers managers, chers CEO, chers Directeurs, chers tous...  Changer de culture, de cadres de travail pour aller vers : le DevOps, l’Agilité, le Lean, c’est bien car on va pouvoir satisfaire le client et délivrer des produits de qualités. Mais il faut savoir que le changement ça prend du temps.   On ne change pas du jour au lendemain.   Dans son livre « Diffusion of Innovations » publié en 1962, Everett Rogers, professeur de sociologie, fournit un cadre complet pour la diffusion de l’innovation.   Il définit cinq groupes de population dont le rapport à la nouveauté varie :   1- Les innovateurs qui sont les plus sensibles à l’innovation.  2- Les premiers adoptants qui sont également friands de nouveauté et se laissent très vite convaincre par les précédents.  3- La majorité précoce qui est constituée de « clients » plus réfléchis qui attendent les retours d’expérience des premiers avant de faire le pas.  4- La majorité tardive qui est bien plus lente dans son processus d’adoption de la nouveauté.   5- Les retardataires qui sont constitués par des personnes qui perçoivent avant tout le changement comme une menace.   Changer ça prend du temps, il faut y aller à un rythme soutenable.

author: Javier Guevara Torres
content: Evolution of successful Digital Banking Models   ● Digital Banks differentiate themselves by being largely based on mobile-centric technology along with more consumer-friendly solutions that operate at a fraction of the marginal and unit cost of their incumbent competitors.   ● They based their business model on finding the solution to customer problems and inadvertently placed profitability in the back seat.  ●Today we have already seen a change in Digital Banks’ priorities. New entrants are focusing on profitability to prove the sustainability of their business model early in the process, whilst the more mature players position themselves for a potential public market entry.  ● As companies scale, goals change, and digital banks are diversifying their revenue sources beyond interchange fees, moving away from fee-free propositions and towards premium, paid banking features such as lending and banking for businesses.  ● An emerging trend of the last few years has been the Super App model. Within all industries, not limited to banking, companies are bundling services, from Apple, Google, PayPal and Amazon, to retailers, telecom companies, FinFech firms and traditional players like Goldman Sachs. All have begun to build propositions around customer lifestyle, bundling financial, shopping, restaurant and travel services (to name a few) with the aim to boost engagement and become a one-stop shop for customers.  ● One of the best examples is Tinkoff , the Russian digital bank that has been profitable for many years now. It has pioneered the Lifestyle Banking model in Russia by bundling value-added services like travel and entertainment bookings, and a mobile network into a Super App to cater to every need.  ●This approach has helped the bank to attract more engaged users , and now Tinkoff Lifestyle customers hold more products and make twice as many monthly purchases than average (non-Lifestyle) Tinkoff customers.  ● Income generated from Tinkoff Lifestyle engagement is then reinvested into customer loyalty via cashback and promotions.   Deeper relationships with consumers and earning loyalty is critical for banks, as it pays off with higher revenues, lower operating costs, and happier customers, the perfect cocktail to attract more customers.  Other digital banks such as Revolut, MoneyLion and SoFi are following a similar approach, aimming to very quickly tailor offerings that become integral to a customer’s lifestyle.  Lear more in C-Innovation latest post. https://lnkd.in/gkP_ViCQ #entreprenership #cinnovation #financialservices #banques #banca #bankingindustry #fintechs #startups #businessmodels #digitalbanking #innovation #fintech #banking #banks #strategy #investment #payments #tech #openbanking #marketplace #superapp

author: Martin Bataille
content: Dear colleagues & friends,      Concerned about climate change, our planet, but struggling to act ? Sad not to have already started a game changing company by yourself ?   No problem, not anyone can develop a new technology or finance a company all by him/her self.      But what we can all do is join our efforts and stand with those who have the ideas  and the innovations to make a change .   How ? Time for the Planet finances companies who develop commercially-viable solutions to either reduce emissions, or capture CO2 in air.   You can invest as little as 1€ for a start.      No return on investment money wise, but I stead you’ll receive CO2 dividends depending on your investment.   If you invest through your company, as I did with Hobent Consulting, this can balance the remaining emissions of your activity (for real, not a fictional CO2 credit).  Real neutrality : your investment in #TimeForThePlanet converts in shares in the companies we will have financed (3 already!) and therefore  represents a proportional share of the CO2 they will have saved / captured.   You can also submit innovations and we will review it. If it checks all boxes  it could be a candidate as the next company created and/or financed !  It’s our generation’s fight, our challenge.   Join us and play your part !   #climatechange #money #technology #finance #investment #change #TFTP #Challenge #today #innovation #consulting

author: Benoit Frère
content: Je ne sais pas vous mais moi quand je postule à une offre d’emploi, je regarde systématiquement :   Attendez pause, FoodChéri l’entreprise/cantine engagée ça vous parle ? Si vous me connaissez bien vous savez que j’attache beaucoup d’importance à la nourriture saine et engagée. Je vous en dit plus ci-dessous.  Reprenons donc où nous en étions dès le départ, moi, quand je postule à une annonce, je checke :  1) Les valeurs de l’entreprise : Et elles sont au nombre de 5 chez eux : -Être responsables (carte mi-végétarienne, réduction empreinte carbone, emballage 100% éco-friendly : plat moyen FoodChéri 770 grammes de Co2 VS Plat moyen en France 1 530 grammes de Co2) -Être bons pour la santé (Cuisine sans additif ni conservateur, 91 % des recettes obtiennent un Nutri-Score A ou B), -Être transparents (transparence des recettes avec les pourcentages sur les ingrédients), -Être innovants (burger aux insectes ou menu au CBD), -Être toujours en action (il y a déjà 5 ans, dès Janvier 2017 : ils proposent une gamme de plats sans gluten et sans lactose). Conclusion : Être aligné avec ces valeurs c’est essentiel pour moi aujourd’hui.  2) La RSE : Chez FoodChéri 96 % de leurs recettes obtiennent un Eco-Score : A ou B. Céréales bio, fruits et légumes de saison, 100% d'œufs plein air, pêche durable et viande labellisée. C’est fou quand même ! En 2022, ce n’est plus possible pour une entreprise d’avoir une vision archaïque et de ne pas penser écologie et environnement. Dois-je vous rappeler les différents sondages pour lesquels les salariés pensent que l’entreprise a un rôle important à jouer dans la politique globale contre le réchauffement climatique ?! Conclusion : A notre échelle, tout le monde doit avoir cette préoccupation là et cette entreprise ne suit pas les tendances, elle les devancent.  3) La QVT (Qualité de Vie au Travail) : So what ?! Q V T 3 lettres qui font encore peur aujourd’hui en entreprise. FoodChéri a clairement compris ça dès le départ. On mange toujours équilibré chez eux le midi et ça change tout ! FoodChéri a d'ailleurs mis cela en avant dans son livre blanc sur « 7 actions concrètes en entreprise pour changer le monde (en commençant par la vie au bureau) ». Conclusion : Lisez ce passionnant livre blanc hyper bien foutu !  FoodChéri = Alfterfoodists = Entreprise engagée  Au fait, qu’est-ce qu’on mange ce midi ?  « Alexandra ça te dit un Japonais ? Oh non Thibault, on a déjà mangé ça la semaine dernière. Ok et tu proposes quoi alors ? Un italien ? T’as pas une autre idée ? »  En panne d’inspiration ?! Marre de toujours manger la même chose ou pire encore des snackings… (aucun jugement de ma part bien entendu)  Et vous, ça vous tente des bons repas équilibrés sur votre lieu de travail ? Yas !  FoodChéri est LA solution pour vos livraisons de repas pour votre pause déjeuner : Bons pour vous, Bons pour la planète et Bons tout court.  #7actionsconcrètes #RSE #cantineengagée #livreblanc #FoodCheri #partenariat  PJ en commentaire : Livre blanc

author: Jean-Philippe Vacher
content: #Industrialization & #decarbonization, what trajectories and solutions emerge among the companies ?  The industrialization of construction is underway, as is the decarbonization of infrastructures and buildings.   Indeed, the challenge is there and in front of us. The French construction majors such as VINCI, Bouygues Construction, Eiffage, Saint-Gobain … should have reduced their carbon footprint by 40% by 2030 and they are sharpening all their strategies and trajectories.  What trajectories facing the carbon challenge? Sobriety meaning the limitation of use and consumptions, the development of short circuits, sustainable mobility, technologies relying on hydrogen and the massive electrification of roads  and modular construction are the strong innovation drivers to reach the successful transformation.   Off site and modular construction ? When it comes to the multifamily modular and prefabricated housing construction market, things are changing in terms of initiatives of certain groups with the offers of industrialized solutions to respond to the urgency of the construction of housing with a low carbon impact as they are intended to be relocatable to be reused or repurposed several times before being transferred to other locations. The different materials include steel, precast concrete, wood, …  Some examples of the majors and industrials’ solutions? For example, Bouygues Construction relies on its #wewood approach by placing construction in wood and biosourced materials at the heart of its strategy while Eiffage group, through its start-up B3 ECODESIGN promotes off-site construction by using last-trip shipping containers as the structure of its buildings to manufacture low-carbon ecological individual houses. For its part the Saint-Gobain group leader in sustainable construction pushes prefabricated houses via the German company BRÜGGEMANN GMBH in Germany while another international building materials specialist of Belgian origin, Etex acquired in 2021 a stake in a leading French company in off-site construction Maisons E-loft becoming part of Etex’s New Ways division. The challenge ahead for these two companies will probably to be successful in building an integrated offer of their industrialized solutions by integrating design, interior layout and thermal and acoustic comfort associated with the exterior decorative finish and its layout using BIM.  #Bouyguesdd #modularconstruction B3 ECODESIGN #sobriety #sustainableworld #mobility #offsitecosntruction #decarbonization #transformation #design #innovation #bim #precastconcrete #plasterboard #cementboard #insulation #lightweight

author: Linwood Pendleton
content: Confused by the new rush of financial tools, offsets, data tech, NFTs, and blockchain into the world of nature conservation? Has our pursuit of measurable impact killed conservation innovation?  In this wide-ranging, 50-minute podcast, Phaedrus and DiamondHands from Planet of the Klimates and I rethink the future of conservation and conservation science in the digital age.   https://lnkd.in/gcaS9Qxy  We discuss the promise and limits of environmental economics and valuing nature, the need for new ways of quantifying the holistic value of nature and the danger of focusing too narrowly on single dimensions like carbon storage. Then we explore the role of blockchain, NFTs, and data tech in achieving a more holistic understanding of nature, creating better incentives to protect nature, and to even create new property rights to protect the creation and sharing of knowledge by local and Indigenous communities as well as scientists and citizens.  Finally, we wrap this up by talking about how Ocean KAN and Moonjelly Academy have created a new, radically transparent approach to bridge web3 and 4IR tech with scientists and researchers to ensure that the rapidly evolving digital world contributes to positive change for the planet.  Leah Karrer Lea Borkenhagen, PhD Bryce Groark Hans Henrik H.  Heming Emily McKenzie Jo Øvstaas Kimberly Mathisen Anna Zivian Stella Alexandroff Adrian Dellecker Ronald Tardiff Janelle Kellman, Esq. (She/Her) Casson Trenor Jason Landrum Charlotte Hudson Katherine Short Guillermo Ortuño Crespo, Ph.D. Linda  B. Ntsiful Torsten Thiele Dorothée Herr #conservation #web3 #ecosystemservices #oceandecade

author: Thomas Triomphe
content: During my time at Sanofi, I have had the privilege of working in Asia, specifically in Singapore and Japan. I’ve witnessed first-hand the strong reputation the region has in being a strategic, innovative, and global hub for biopharmaceutical manufacturing, with Singapore very much at the forefront of this.    Today, I'm especially honored to be joined by Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Coordinating Minister for Economic Policies, Heng Swee Keat, to lay the first stone for our Evolutive Vaccine Facility (EVF) here in Singapore.    EVFs represent a revolutionary technological and industrial transformation that will enable us to significantly increase our production capacity of any vaccine and to rapidly adapt to changes in vaccine demand. Our EVF in Singapore will be the first facility of its kind in Asia, and we’re pleased to be a part of such an active regional hub of innovation in the healthcare sector. It will be a sister site to our EVF in Neuville-sur-Saône, France, on which we broke ground last month.     I want to share a big thank you to all the teams involved in this project. I can’t wait to see our Singapore EVF come to life! If you’re curious, you can learn more about our EVFs here: https://lnkd.in/ekW_ngWg

author: Julien Peron Neorizons - Neo-bienetre
content: Dans un très bel article, Arthur Mantes, auteur du blog Science de Soi, nous livre des clefs pour prendre conscience que nous sommes les créateurs de notre réalité, et que ce sont nos pensées et émotions qui génèrent notre vie. Il est temps de comprendre que nous détenons un pouvoir merveilleux, et qu’il ne tient qu’à nous de l’utiliser positivement. Voulez-vous apprendre cette capacité qui fait de vous le créateur conscient de votre vie ?  1 - Prendre conscience de son pouvoir créateur  Cela signifie clairement que tout ce dont vous faites l’expérience est le fruit de ce que vous avez été jusqu’ici. « Demandez, et vous aurez », c’est la loi de l’attraction. Cette loi dit que ce que l’on vibre, on l’attire dans notre réalité. Il ne s’agit pas vraiment de demander, mais plutôt d’incarner la vibration que l’on souhaite voir manifester dans sa vie.  Ceci n’est pas dans nos habitudes, car le mode de fonctionnement “ classique “ consiste à d’abord obtenir une chose et ensuite se sentir bien. Et si la clé résidait dans le fait de se sentir bien en avance, et que c’était là la condition pour que la vie s’aligne sur notre vrai désir ? C’est le mode de fonctionnement quantique, et cela ne peut pas fonctionner autrement. Vous ne pouvez obtenir quelque chose si vous vibrez différemment de cette chose. C’est donc à vous de faire l’effort de changer votre vibration, afin que votre vie change en conséquence, et que vous puissiez attirer à vous les choses que vous désirez vraiment. C’est toute la mécanique de la réalité qui fonctionne comme cela : un être humain est une antenne, dont le champ d’énergie est constitué par les pensées et les émotions, et sa réalité correspond au champ qu’il émet.  Donc la plupart des gens ne font que constater que leur vie n’est pas comme ils le voudraient, et s’alignent alors sur une signature émotionnelle de déception, de plainte, de souffrance, de renoncement. C’est pourquoi ils réitèrent encore et encore les même expériences, en boucle. Et alors, ils ne comprennent pas pourquoi ils souffrent autant, pourquoi la vie est si dure et injuste et pour quelle raison ils sont autant victimes des circonstances. Mais sachez que la loi d’attraction est une loi neutre, et personne n’en n’est victime. Jamais ! La plupart des gens demandent des solutions magiques mais refusent de croire en la magie. Acceptez de croire que les choses dépendent de vous, que vous êtes responsable de votre vie et que, malgré les apparences, vous avez un réel pouvoir personnel sur la réalité dont vous faites l’expérience.  Article complet https://lnkd.in/gHYCrje  Vous aimez mes articles? Vous allez adorer notre magazine Innovation en Éducation  https://lnkd.in/gkx6XTE  Vous pouvez également vous procurer le n°1 « Tout part de l’éducation » et le n°2 « Cerveau et neurosciences, enfin le mode d’emploi » dans notre boutique en ligne ici https://lnkd.in/gQBU_PfK

author: Olivier Salomon
content: 1. “Low-cost, zero carbon #electricity: So far wind, solar and lithium batteries have moved the needle forward. But we haven’t solved electricity. Development of nuclear will be a key factor in creating resilience to the inevitable rising demand for clean electricity. 2. Confront industrial emitters: Steel, cement, chemicals and aluminum… 30% of all GHG emissions come from manufacturing alone. Pressure on these producers is coming from every direction - consumers, activists, employees and shareholders are rallying demands for industrial #decarbonisation. 3. Solve transportation: We’re already seeing momentum building for electric vehicles and #micromobility, but there is also room for transition to #biofuels, and big change must happen for industrial shipping. Innovation for this can speed up as clean electricity becomes more widely available. 4. Build the carbon management industry: It’s time to create a massive market for the capture and removal, storage, transportation, and finance of the net zero transition… We need to account for 10 gigatons of #carbon. At $100 per ton, that’s a trillion dollar market. 5. Decarbonise Maslow’s basic needs: Everybody on the planet requires food and shelter. This means agriculture and construction - with steel, cement, aluminum, and lumber. These big industries must shift to net zero as well.”

author: Preston Dunlap
content: It’s almost time to pass the baton.  25,000 miles per hour is fast.  But that speed is necessary to defy the gravitational pull of the earth.  Defying gravity is hard, but not impossible.   Similarly, driving innovation and change in a large organization - let alone the largest organization on the planet, the Department of Defense - is hard, but not impossible.  I’ve spent the last 3 years working to defy gravity and get desperately needed technology into our operators’ hands.   Some of that technology was previously unimaginable.  At other times it was previously unattainable – available commercially, yet beyond DoD’s grasp.   In every case, my team and I achieved meaningful change in defiance of a constant, powerful gravitational pull to the status quo.  Talk is easy; action is hard.  For over 3 years it’s been my privilege to serve as the first Chief Architect Officer of the Department of the Air Force, overseeing the architecture of over $70 billion of U.S. Space Force and U.S. Air Force research, development, and acquisition programs.  I would not have been able to accelerate necessary change without the steadfast trust, partnership, and leadership from the very top: Deputy Secretary of Defense Norquist and Hicks; Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs Gen Hyten; Secretary of the Air Force Wilson, Barrett, and Kendall; Chief of Space Operations Gen Raymond;  Chief of Staff of the Air Force Gen Goldfein and Gen Brown; and Assistant Secretary, Will Roper and Andrew Hunter. I'm grateful to each of them for their dedication to our nation, for making delivery of needed capabilities a critical priority, and for their trust in me and my team to allow the freedom of maneuver to accelerate at speed and scale.  I believe in passing the baton. So, I’ve attached a long letter that I hope serves as encouragement that anyone can defy gravity and make change happen – even at the largest employer in the galaxy and with small but highly capable teams.    But, we should never be satisfied. We need this kind of progress at scale now, not tomorrow. So let’s be careful to not...  --Lull ourselves into complacency, when we should be running on all cylinders.  --Do things the same way, when we should be doing things better.  --Distract ourselves with process, when we should be focused on delivering product.  --Compete with each other, when we should be competing with China.  --Defend our turf, when we should be defending our country.  --Focus on input metrics, when we should be focused on output metrics.  --Buy the same things, when we should be investing in what we need.  --Be comfortable with the way things are, when we should be fighting for the way things should be.  Thank you to the amazing and talented Chief Architect Office team and the countless partners across DoD and industry; too many to tag here.    Now, let's make the last couple weeks of my tenure count and move more items from the "getting stuff done" to the "got stuff done" list!

author: Marena Eirich
content: #TBT The IPCC published its report on Climate Change #Mitigation last week.  These stats are pretty serious:  The average annual emissions in the last decade have been the highest in human history. We are NOT on track towards 1,5°C global warming, and we are already at 1,1°C. Emissions need to peak within 3 years (by 2025) and have to be reduced rapidly (-43% by 2030) to avoid dramatic consequences.  The cost of action is still lower than the cost of inaction.   So how can your business be part of the solution?   The report says that solutions exist for ALL industries. Have a look in which areas your organization can take Climate action:  Energy  Increase energy efficiency, electrification and alternative fuels.  Reduce or stop using coal, petrol and natural gas.  Transport  Use low carbon mobility.  Reduce demand, travel less, purchase locally   Industry  Use efficient materials, enhance circularity and low emissions production processes.  Reduce waste and fossil-based energy sources.  Tech & Innovation  Make sure tech innovations are low emissions (e.g. digital sobriety, green IT...).  Don't invest in high emissions tech (e.g. big data requiring more servers to be heated ...).  Finance   Financing: sufficient global capital is available but at the moment it's six (!) times lower than what is needed.  Stop funding fossil-intensive industries; change your banking partner to support sustainable banks.   Nature   Restore or protect #biodiversity. Make sure to buy food from suppliers with sustainable agri-practices, sustainably sourced raw materials (e.g. enhance circularity versus "virgin" mining)  Stop destroying and polluting natural "carbon sinks". Natural "carbon sinks" are forests, wetlands, oceans, soils, mangroves...   There’s no quickly scalable artificial carbon capture tech available, so we need to protect our natural "carbon sinks", so they can continue to absorb our extra GHG emissions.  If we continue destroying nature and biodiversity, we destroy our means of removing GHG from the atmosphere.    What you can do: get informed and share!  - Inform yourself and share the latest IPCC report - Check out the great video summary by Axa Climate School in various languages  - 13 ways you can take climate action as a Business by teams4purpose  —> links in the comments   Last but not least: an image speaks louder than words…  This is what we need right now - collective Climate action to bring emissions down, fast.  Image credit : petitesquisses Elsa Forneris #climatechange #biodiversityloss

author: Chris Igwe
content: World Retail Congress #2 - My personal take aways.   I must acknowledge the winners of the Future Retail Challenge - the Italian School. On stage, all the contestants were refreshingly insightful. Steffi Lomba Vrouenraets, who I spoke with graciously accepted that she and her team were unsuccessful, but mentioned the pressure they were all under. With the words of wisdom from such young minds, the future of retail is in good hands!   Day 2: Tobias Wasmuht, CEO of SPAR International reminded us that despite the multitude of current crises the two constants for years to come will be Digital and Sustainability.   Paul Polman, Former CEO of Unilever, and Co Author of the book, Net Positive, gave us some stark reminders that Food and Fashion are the two contributors to our current issues. Paradoxically, they are also the key to finding a solution to sustainability. By taking responsibility, they can save humanity. Paul pointed out that "less bad" is not good enough! He closed by saying that we need to look at long term strategies and not quarterly reports or favouring shareholder returns.....a theme echoed by many who spoke at this year's Congress.  There was a standing ovation for Paul, the only one of the Congress, so it resonated. Now it is about turning claps into action! As he said, we need more leadership - people who care and show courage.   Alex Baldock, CEO of Currys plc spoke about Winning with Omnichannel. I was particularly impressed not only by his presentation but by the fact that this tired old concept I knew when I lived in the UK is transformed to be such a strong brand. Alex described the need for accountability at leadership level, but which must also conveyed to all levels of the organisation, such that they are able to address and meet the needs of a changed consumer for whom technology should be made fun and easily navigable.  He reminded us that customers are accustomed to "frictionless". By embracing this mindset, Currys has boosted its online business significantly.   Cathy Sparks, VP, EMEA, Nike Direct, reassured us of the importance of physical stores and the brand's commitment to driving better customer service and building communities. Cathy also confirmed that its first Nike Rise format in EMEA will be opening at the Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield centre, Westfield London.   Suzanne Santos, Chief Customer Officer, Aesop, a brand I love, rounded off the day reminding us how important customer service is. She notes that customers, especially since Covid, want to "be in contemplation and in conversation" with the store consultants. Customers, she said, want to get more informed about the packaging and sourcing than before.   She closed by saying that the Future of Retail is about Tactility, Conversations and Intimacy.  Great capturing of the key aspects of speeches by Innovation Arts. Brilliant work!  #winningmindset #fashionindustry #techinnovation #youthleaders #globalvoiceofretail CHRIS IGWE INTERNATIONAL

author: Sylvie Veyret
content: [2008] Pamela Warhurst, réunit quelques habitants de Todmorden -une ancienne cité textile anglaise qui se meurt- pour leurs parler de son projet «relancer les énergies de tous pour créer quelque chose ensemble et reprendre le pouvoir.»    Une idée émerge :   planter des légumes, les partager et les cuisiner ensemble     Le petit groupe de citoyens colonise l'espace publique et quelques mois plus tard: 70 cagettes remplies de légumes sont disposées sur un trottoir avec un panneau « Nourritures à partager ».     Incredible Edible est né et provoque une réaction en chaîne: ⇨ Le petit groupe s’agrandit et plante des arbres fruitiers ⇨ Puis il convainc les fermiers à 80km à la ronde, de ne plus vendre aux grandes surfaces mais dans les magasins locaux où ils sont maîtres de leur marge. ⇨ Les enfants élèvent des poules à l’école et cultivent les légumes qu’ils vont consommer à la cantine.    En 2011, 83% de la nourriture consommée à Todmorden est locale et l'aventure a boosté la dynamique de toute la communauté…    La permaculture, la gastronomie attirent les touristes. ⇨ Pour les accueillir : boutiques, restaurants et hôtels rouvrent pour devenir 2 fois plus nombreux qu’en 2008. ⇨L’expérimentation ne s’arrête pas là, elle est devenue permanente: des plats cuisinés avec des goûts inédits, la construction d’un hôtel avec un éco-matériaux à base de paille…plus personne n’a peur d’échouer…      Incredible Edible deviendra Les Incroyables Comestibles en France et partout dans le monde de telles initiatives naissent.     Et voilà comment une innovation basée sur l’intelligence collective et née de l’énergie d’un petit groupe change tout un paysage de désolation.      « Ne doutez jamais qu’un petit groupe de citoyens engagés et réfléchis puisse changer le monde. En réalité c'est toujours ce qui s'est passé. » _Margaret Mead    Une histoire à partager ? Surtout n’hésitez pas, nous avons besoin d’exemples…    Pour en savoir plus : https://lnkd.in/eJcnY3Mc #innovation #intelligencecollective #énergie

content: After two years, I am delighted to graduate from University College Cork with a MSc Project Management. content: I am pleased to have started mentoring on The Greenhouse accelerator at the Centre for Climate Change Innovation, a partnership between Imperial College London and The Royal Institution. Using the volunteering time provided by JLL to work on causes that matter, I am supporting Angry Monk which helps businesses fight climate change with rescue food direct from local markets and farms. Working with founders Nathan Lucaussy & Andrea G., the aim is to rescue 1 billion kg as a direct of the Angry Monk digital platform.  Thanks to Sophie Van Eetvelt and Naveed Chaudhry for their brilliant work in putting the programme together, and inviting me to be a part of it  #mentoring #climate #innovation

author: GARBA Moussa, PhD
content: #Mentorship  never stop learning  Throughput my academic and professional career, I have come to notice that what makes a teacher great is simply his ability and passion to continuous learning. I never stop learning, because life never stops teaching me. Things are moving and changing. Innovations are coming into being.   Despite my busy schedule as a data scientist, data analyst and a PhD in the domain, I always afford time to learn, to be mentored while mentoring others.  The quite golden time I have spent with  Codementor has enabled me to discover countless things such as:  1. Being able to blend learning and teaching processes:  2. Mentoring and being mentored; 3. Broadening my spectrum of thought 4. Interacting with people, regardless of their level of knowledge is always beneficial to you  This has undoubtedly helped me to shape and improve on my own skill, set to integrate the new models effectively in my set of data. Our world is speedily getting modernised coupled with new discoveries.  Knowledge is something infinite and there's no limitation of what one should learn. Learn Statistics Through Practice

author: Dominique de Saint Laurent
content: Est ce que vous connaissez le concept WELOGE, l'immobilier tout compris ?  Weloge c’est avant tout une communauté d’entrepreneurs ambitieux et profondément altruistes qui partagent les mêmes valeurs et ont à cœur d’apporter des solutions clé en main et des services innovants à leurs clients.  Weloge c’est une offre de 8 services pour aider nos clients à valoriser et vendre leur bien immobilier au top de leur valeur et dans un délai record.   Weloge c’est le 1er réseau et l’unique réseau en France de consultants indépendants en valorisation immobilière.  Weloge c’est une entreprise qui a réalisé une croissance de 280% en 2021 et qui enchaîne les mois record en 2022.   Weloge c’est une entreprise que j’ai fondé en 2017 avec le cœur pour des personnes qui veulent se réaliser pleinement et s’épanouir autant sur le plan personnel que professionnel.   Weloge recrute partout en France des hommes, des femmes de tout horizon qui ont avant tout, un savoir être.  Peu importe le savoir faire, 98% des welogeurs n’avaient aucune compétence, ni expérience en immobilier, des personnes qui se sont formés avec nous et qui réussissent très bien aujourd’hui.   Vous aussi vous avez envie de prendre votre vie en main ?  Je vous invite  à participer à la web conférence que j’aurai grand plaisir à animer le lundi 25 avril à 18h30 : "Se réinventer et entreprendre autrement".   Je partagerai des clés de réussite et présenterai le concept #weloge qui change des vies !  Je mets le lien en 1er commentaire  . . . .  #reconversionprofessionnelle #weloge #entrepreneurheureux #lancersaboiteen2022

author: Vyashini Chokupermal
content: Exploring the future of plant proteins in oceans  In today’s time, consumers awareness of environmental, health and animal welfare issues are expected to propel the growth of plant-based protein market. This boom in demand offers substantial opportunities for algae which appears to be an interesting ingredient for food processors who are anticipating changing consumer trends. “More than 70 % of the Earth’s surface is covered with water, inhabited by a wide variety of algae, but only a handful of them is being exploited. There’s so much space for innovation in terms of texture and flavour! Seaweed cultivation is not only a step towards sustainable development, but it is also a gateway to regenerative agriculture” stated Jacob von Manteuffel during the webinar hosted by ProVeg International on the topic “algae and their various applications in the food industry”  However, there are multiple challengesthat need to be addressed. The change in scale of production requires new infrastructures and the optimisation of industrial processes. Regulations in different maritime areas can make it difficult to exploit algae. In addition, unlocking the right functionalities for food formulation, providing applications that are user-friendly, having sufficient raw materials and co-products, achieving a competitive price, and controlling pollutants in the oceans are still major difficulties that lie ahead. ALGAMA Foods  Alvyn Severien Oceanfruit BettaF!sh Alexander Golberg  Read more on Les Marchés #protéinesvégétales #plantbasedprotein #carbone #innovation #seaweed
